2 Basic Bookdown 2.1 R code 2.2 Figures 2.3 Tables

2 Basic Bookdown 2.1 R code This is a sample r code. Just like .rmd file, Some code ould be embeded in linernorm(10) and results is 0.7255467, 0.9635054, -0.7512086, -0.697568, 1.3546897, 0.2033075, 2.2724609, 1.5187621, -0.1585771, 0.5423169. Or you can put them in a code chunk: 1 + 1 ## [1] 2 rnorm(10) # 10 random numbers ## [1] -0.16398300 -0.27158736 -0.04335216 0.15622989 0.85347279 ## [6] -0.65927631 -0.77871977 1.14687526 0.67212827 1.23827786 plot(dist ~ speed, cars) # a scatterplot Figure 2.1: A figure caption. 2.2 Figures Figures and tables with captions will be placed in figure and table environments, respectively. par(mar = c(4, 4, .1, .1)) plot(pressure, type = 'b', pch = 19) Figure 2.2: Here is a nice figure! Reference a figure by its code chunk label with the fig: prefix, e.g., see Figure 2.2. Similarly, you can reference tables generated from knitr::kable(), e.g., see Table 2.1. 2.3 Tables knitr::kable( head(iris, 20), caption = 'Here is a nice table!', booktabs = TRUE ) Table 2.1: Here is a nice table! 3 Advanced Bookdown 3.1 Surface Plot-plotly 3.2 Map with Date-leaflet 3.3 Citation You can store your citation in a plain text .bib file and then cite it simply by @key. For example, R Core Team (2016) and NA (2019) References
